documentation.title: About the uploading my presentation video on internet and the Ethical Issues
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have one presentation about "*the effect of AI on music industry*" in one [academic research NGO](https://www.gicnetwork.be/the-ngo-ization-of-academic-research/) group which is created on WhatsApp, and I want to know if I publish the video of my presentation via my post about that field or upload it on YouTube is it right (legal) and does it require any approval from the group admin or ...?

Thanks.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Taking the linked paper as a hypothetical case, the author might have a contractal obligation with the NGO or the research institute that limits ability to freely distribute materials created "on the job", so you might have to ask your boss. Otherwise, you might think that because the material was initially recorded on WhatsApp (I surmise), there might be a requirement to get permission. So you turn to the [WhatsApp terms of service](https://www.whatsapp.com/legal/updates/terms-of-service/?lang=en), in the section on licenses. The first thing they say is

> WhatsApp does not claim ownership of the information that you submit
> for your WhatsApp account or through our Services.

So you don't need their permission to redistribute material that you created using that platform.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An academic researcher creates a presentation on "the effect of AI on the music industry" for a WhatsApp-based research group affiliated with an NGO. The researcher wants to publish the video of this presentation on YouTube. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal and ethical considerations?

A) The researcher must obtain explicit permission from WhatsApp before publishing the video, as it was initially shared on their platform.

B) The researcher needs approval only from the WhatsApp group admin to publish the video, regardless of any NGO affiliations.

C) The researcher should check their contractual obligations with the NGO or research institute before publishing, as there may be restrictions on distributing work-related materials.

D) The researcher has full rights to publish the video without any permissions, as WhatsApp does not claim ownership of user-submitted content.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While WhatsApp does not claim ownership of user-submitted content, the researcher's primary consideration should be their contractual obligations with the NGO or research institute. These organizations may have policies or agreements in place regarding the distribution of work-related materials. The correct approach is to review any existing contracts or policies and, if necessary, consult with supervisors or administrators before publishing the video. This ensures compliance with any potential restrictions or requirements set by the affiliated organization, which takes precedence over the general terms of the communication platform used.

documentation.title: Where do I put an Impressum on my client's website
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: We are busy building one of our first websites for a client in the European market. My client has asked that we add an Impressum to their site. I have been reading about these, and it seems pretty straight forward. I would however like to make sure that I am doing everything correctly, as this appears to be a legal requirement, meaning any miss\-step on my end could prove detrimental to my client.

I had initially thought that this information would be something akin to the metadata for the author of a website, but I am coming to understand that it is actually content that should be displayed on the website. I am thus thinking of placing this on the contact page of the site.

My questions are thus this... Do I understand correctly that:

this is the basic information of the owner of the site (name, address, tax info, etc)
that this information needs to be visible to the end\-user
that there is no particular place that this needs to be visible (like on every page in the footer for example)
and, that placing it on the contact page would suffice
I would greatly appreciate any advice that anyone would be able to offer in this regard. Many thanks in advance!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: According to information (in German) on the website [impressum\-recht.de](http://www.impressum-recht.de/impressum-kontakt-angaben.html):

> Die Nutzer sollten auch am besten von jeder einzelnen Seite der Webseite die Anbieterkennzeichnung erreichen können.

> Users should also be able to reach the provider identification from every single page of the website.

The page continues to suggest two options \- either directly including the information on each page, or a link to another page containing the info.

However: there appears to be no need for this page to be labelled Impressum \-

> als Bezeichnung bieten sich "Impressum" oder "Kontakt" an;

> as a designation "imprint" or "contact" are suitable;

There are some more useful tips about the placement and nature of the page on the linked site, which I encourage you to read (it translates well with [DeepL translation](https://www.deepl.com/)).

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to German law regarding website "Impressum" requirements, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) The Impressum information must be visible on every page of the website in the footer.

B) The Impressum can only be labeled as "Impressum" and must be on a separate page from the contact information.

C) The Impressum information or a link to it should be accessible from every page of the website, and can be labeled as either "Impressum" or "Contact".

D) The Impressum is optional for websites targeting the European market and can be omitted if detailed contact information is provided elsewhere on the site.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, the Impressum information or a link to it should be accessible from every page of the website ("Users should also be able to reach the provider identification from every single page of the website."). Additionally, the designation can be either "Impressum" or "Contact" ("as a designation 'imprint' or 'contact' are suitable"). 

Option A is incorrect because while the information should be accessible from every page, it doesn't necessarily need to be in the footer. 

Option B is incorrect because the Impressum can be labeled as either "Impressum" or "Contact", and it doesn't have to be separate from contact information. 

Option D is incorrect because the Impressum is a legal requirement for websites in certain European countries, particularly Germany, and cannot be omitted.

documentation.title: Is it legal to create a cryptocurrency?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I want to create a new cryptocurrency as an experiment. Is this legal?

My cryptocurrency won't use a blockchain, so laws specifically regulating blockchains might not apply.

The system will be completely decentralized. Mining doesn't create any form of control over another user's transactions, so a majority of mining being done by one entity wouldn't be a problem at all other than the possibility of them disrupting operation by just ceasing to mine, so a "51% attack" is impossible.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes
---

In general, the default is that it is legal to do anything unless it isn't. That's how cryptocurrencies happened in the first place.

Of course, you will have to follow laws that are applicable to cryptocurrencies and not do anything illegal with them or your business.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Based on the information given about creating a new cryptocurrency, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal status and characteristics of the proposed system?

A) Creating a new cryptocurrency is inherently illegal due to its decentralized nature and potential for anonymous transactions.

B) The proposed cryptocurrency would be exempt from all existing cryptocurrency regulations because it doesn't use a blockchain.

C) The legality of creating a new cryptocurrency depends on following applicable laws, but it is generally permissible unless specifically prohibited.

D) The impossibility of a "51% attack" in this system automatically makes it legal and free from any regulatory oversight.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because the documentation states that "the default is that it is legal to do anything unless it isn't," and that cryptocurrencies are generally legal as long as creators "follow laws that are applicable to cryptocurrencies and not do anything illegal with them or your business." 

Option A is incorrect because creating a cryptocurrency is not inherently illegal. 

Option B is misleading because while blockchain-specific regulations might not apply, other cryptocurrency laws could still be relevant. 

Option D is incorrect because the technical features of the system, such as resistance to a "51% attack," do not automatically determine its legal status or exempt it from regulations.

documentation.title: Freezing funds with positive balance
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: My spouse's son is on an account with his stepmother. Both were put on the account at different times by his dad. Unfortunately his dad passed away recently. The money in the account was to be split 50/50\. The stepmother started withdrawing money immediately after her husband's death. The son inquired about the balance. It was considerably lower than expected. Now the bank froze all assets. Question: shouldn't he still he allowed to withdraw at will? Him and his stepmother are both legal owners of the account. Also, we don't know of any will.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Banks often freeze accounts when ownership appears to be disputed. While being a co\-signer can provide authority to withdraw funds from an account, it only sometimes implies ownership of all of the funds contained in it that can be withdrawn at will.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the given information:

Question: In a situation where a joint bank account holder passes away, and there are disputes between the surviving account holders regarding fund withdrawals, what is the most likely immediate action taken by the bank?

A) Allow unrestricted withdrawals by all surviving account holders
B) Distribute the funds equally among surviving account holders
C) Freeze the account pending resolution of ownership disputes
D) Transfer all funds to the deceased's estate

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: When there are disputes or uncertainties regarding the ownership of funds in a joint account after one account holder's death, banks typically freeze the account as a precautionary measure. This action prevents any further withdrawals until the ownership issues are resolved, protecting both the bank and the potential rightful owners of the funds. 

Option A is incorrect because allowing unrestricted withdrawals could lead to improper distribution of funds. 
Option B is not typically done by banks without legal direction. 
Option C is correct as it's the standard procedure to protect all parties involved. 
Option D would only be done under specific legal circumstances and is not the immediate action taken by banks in such situations.

documentation.title: Is asking someone to take photos of houses illegal without permission?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: For private purposes, would it be illegal if someone asked/paid a person to take photos of the outside of houses and send them to the person from which the photos are never publicly advertised or used for any commercial/monetary purposes \-\- but no express consent of any kind is established.

Mind that this is only the outside front of houses and contains no other identifying information.

One reason this might be for is eventually considering uploading them for Google/public maps.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In the US it is legal to take pictures of the parts of a house that are visible from public property. By legal I mean that there is no law forbidding it but you might break some other laws while you are doing it.

The reason that I say "from public property" is that the homeowner has no reasonable expectation of privacy.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the United States, which of the following scenarios regarding photographing private residences is most likely to be considered legal?

A) Taking photos of the interior of a house through an open window from the sidewalk
B) Entering a homeowner's backyard to photograph the rear of the house without permission
C) Photographing the front exterior of a house from a public street
D) Using a drone to capture aerial images of a house's rooftop and backyard

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) While this is taken from public property, it may violate privacy expectations for the interior of a home.
B) This involves trespassing on private property, which is illegal.
C) This is legal because the front of the house is visible from public property, and there's no reasonable expectation of privacy.
D) Drone photography may violate privacy laws and FAA regulations, especially over private property.

The correct answer is C because photographing the exterior of a house from a public street does not violate any laws in the US. There is no reasonable expectation of privacy for parts of a house visible from public areas, and no trespassing is involved.

documentation.title: What is the legal requirements of earning money on the internet
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am planning to provide an internet service that accepts payments through

1. Bit coin
2. PayPal
3. Visa

For now, I have not legally registered this as a company or planning to pay tax for the income.
Is it illegal to do this? And what do I need to do before starting to earn income?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is illegal to not declare income to the IRS.

Self\-employment tax rules apply to all income. Bitcoin is treated as property and is taxable.

[https://www.irs.gov/uac/newsroom/irs\-virtual\-currency\-guidance](https://www.irs.gov/uac/newsroom/irs-virtual-currency-guidance)

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: John is starting an online service that accepts payments through Bitcoin, PayPal, and Visa. He hasn't registered his business or planned to pay taxes on the income. Which of the following statements is correct regarding John's tax obligations?

A) John doesn't need to report his income or pay taxes since he hasn't officially registered his business.
B) John only needs to report and pay taxes on income received through PayPal and Visa, as Bitcoin is not considered taxable.
C) John must report all income, including Bitcoin transactions, and pay self-employment tax on his earnings.
D) John can wait until his business becomes profitable before reporting income and paying taxes.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to IRS guidelines, all income, regardless of the source or whether the business is officially registered, must be reported for tax purposes. This includes income from Bitcoin transactions, which the IRS treats as property for tax purposes. Self-employment tax rules apply to all income earned through self-employment activities. Therefore, John is legally obligated to report all income from his online service, including payments received through Bitcoin, PayPal, and Visa, and pay the appropriate self-employment taxes. Failing to do so would be considered tax evasion and is illegal.

documentation.title: Does U.S.C Title 18 Section 2512 apply to "wireless auditing tools?"
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Tools such as the "WiFi pineapple" are rising in popularity in penetration testing and hacking communities. These devices are designed to allow and explicitly marketed as being able to intercept WiFi communications. They are sold online to anyone who wants one. My question is weather or not these count as "communication intercepting devices" as defined by Section 2512\. A well known version of this type of tool, the WiFi pineapple (<https://www.wifipineapple.com/>) specifically advertises the ability to intercept communications. To clarify, I'm trying to find out why they get a seeming exemption, and what would be too "far" to be legal for my own experimentation with wireless security hardware. The why it is fairly important so I know where to start for my own research.

Is it illegal to Manufacture, distribute, possess, or advertise the WiFi pineapple or similar devices, per Section 2512?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: On the face of it, manufacturing such devices is a crime (but there is no civil remedy against the manufacturer if you get intercepted: see [Javier Luis v. Awareness Technologies](http://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-6th-circuit/1746140.html) for a similar device:

> The complaint therefore adequately alleges a violation of 18 U.S.C. §
>  2512(1\)(b). This leads to the question whether Luis can sue for that
>  violation. Section 2512(1\)(b) itself does not allow for such a suit
>  because it provides only that the violator will be “fined ․ or
>  imprisoned.” Luis's private cause of action for such a violation thus
>  depends on the proper interpretation of 18 U.S.C. § 2520\.

Criminal prosecution can happen, see [US v. McNutt](https://law.resource.org/pub/us/case/reporter/F2/908/908.F2d.561.89-5167.89-5153.html), [US v. Splawn](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/963/295/243369/), for cases involving satellite descramblers. It is most likely that these devices intercept electronic communication: there is a loophole regarding stored communication, but it is likely that these devices pass the contemporaneity test. There is no requirement that manufacturers be prosecuted, but it is a possibility. One point that we can't determine (too compu\-technical) is whether the devices are primarily manufactured for legal use by government and communication providers.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to the information provided about WiFi pineapple devices and similar tools, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding their legal status under Section 2512?

A) Manufacturing and distributing WiFi pineapple devices is always legal because they are primarily used for legitimate penetration testing.

B) Possessing a WiFi pineapple device is illegal for private individuals, but legal for government agencies and communication providers.

C) Manufacturing WiFi pineapple devices could potentially be prosecuted as a crime, but there is no civil remedy for individuals whose communications are intercepted by such devices.

D) Advertising WiFi pineapple devices is explicitly prohibited by Section 2512, while manufacturing and distribution fall into a legal gray area.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The information provided indicates that manufacturing devices like the WiFi pineapple could potentially be considered a crime under Section 2512. However, the case of Javier Luis v. Awareness Technologies establishes that there is no civil remedy for individuals whose communications are intercepted by such devices. The answer also reflects the complexity of the legal situation, as it doesn't definitively state that manufacturing is always illegal, but rather that it could be subject to prosecution. Options A and B are incorrect because they make overly broad statements about legality that aren't supported by the given information. Option D is incorrect because while advertising might be questionable, the information doesn't explicitly state that it's prohibited while manufacturing and distribution are in a gray area.

documentation.title: Holding harmless to the extent it infringes on others
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I was reading [example](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2010/06/how-to-spot-a-sketchy-client-plus-a-contract-template/) contracts and found this phrase I don't fully understand:

> Client expressly agrees that it will hold the Designer harmless for
>  all liability caused by the Client’s use of the Designer’s product to
>  the extent such use infringes on the rights of others.

In plain English, what does it mean? In particular I find confusing the last part "to the extent such use infringes on the rights of others". Does it mean:

1. If the client infringed on the rights of others, he will hold harmless the designer for this.
2. The client will always hold harmless the designer, to the maximum extent just before he infringes on others rights by doing so.
3. Something different.
4. Both 1\. and 2\., it is ambiguous.

This seems to be a very broad statement. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your first interpretation is correct.

In this case, "to the extent" means, in a very rough sense, "if".

A plain English gloss of this (minus some nuance) would be:

> If the client's use of the designer's product causes liability; and
> 
> 
> if the liability arises from the use infringing on the rights of others;
> 
> 
> then the client expressly agrees that it will hold the designer harmless.

However, "to the extent" is used because it is envisioned that liability may arise for a number of reasons. The designer is held harmless only for liability arising from an infringing use. That is, "to the extent such use infringes on the rights of others". Liability arising from other reasons is not covered by the clause.

7.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A graphic designer includes the following clause in their contract with a client:

"Client expressly agrees that it will hold the Designer harmless for all liability caused by the Client's use of the Designer's product to the extent such use infringes on the rights of others."

Which of the following best describes the legal implications of this clause?

A) The client must indemnify the designer for any liability, regardless of whether it's related to infringement or not.

B) The designer is protected from liability only if the client's use of the product infringes on others' rights, and only to the extent of that infringement.

C) The client is responsible for all liabilities arising from their use of the product, except those related to infringement of others' rights.

D) The clause is too ambiguous to be enforceable and would likely be struck down in court.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct interpretation of this clause is that the client agrees to hold the designer harmless (i.e., indemnify or protect from legal responsibility) for liability caused by the client's use of the designer's product, but only to the extent that such use infringes on the rights of others. 

Option A is incorrect because the indemnification is limited to infringement-related liability, not "any liability."

Option B correctly captures the nuanced meaning of "to the extent," which limits the designer's protection to cases where the client's use infringes on others' rights, and only for the liability arising from that infringement.

Option C is the opposite of what the clause actually states, so it's incorrect.

Option D is incorrect because while the clause may seem broad, it has a specific legal meaning that courts would likely uphold.

This question tests understanding of legal language, the concept of indemnification, and the importance of precise wording in contracts.

documentation.title: Eligibility to build on a FL Condominium Common Area?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Florida Condominiums are governed by FS718

Assume that:

1. the condo owners are not licensed Florida builders.
2. they have built wooden decks or concrete patios behind their units on the condominium common area.
3. there are no records of permits , inspections, or authorization from the association for owners to build said items. Florida builder licensing is regulated by the Florida [DBPR](https://www.myfloridalicense.com/wl11.asp?mode=0&SID=).

**Question 1:** What if any statute requires that the the wooden decks or concrete patios built on the common areas must be built by a Florida licensed contractor?

**Question 2:** Is anyone other than a Florida Licensed Contractor eligible to build wooden decks \& concrete patios on the Florida condominium common areas?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A few general reactions:

1. Building anything on common HOA property without HOA permission probably violates the HOA governing documents. The HOA could probably fine you or enjoin you from doing so. If you had followed the HOA process to build something, it would probably have imposed requirements upon who could do the work. This said, if it is a limited common element serving one unit, rather than a general common element serving all units, the HOA might be more tolerant.
2. But, frequently there is a statute of limitations that is fairly short to complain about building a structure without permission or without a proper permit.
3. Not all construction work requires building permits or contractor's licenses. A simple patio or deck might not require one. Typically, a local government enacts a version of the Uniform Building Code and you'd have to check municipal ordinances.
4. Building permits are usually administered by local government, rather than state government officials.
5. A local government that becomes aware of a structure that required a permit but was built without one, when the statute of limitations has run on insisting that it be destroyed, might still deny further permits for the relevant property until the non\-conforming structure is removed.

The legal analysis would depend to some extent on how the issue presented itself. Who is complaining and in what forum? What relief are they seeking?

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A Florida condominium owner, without obtaining HOA permission or proper permits, built a wooden deck on the condominium's common area five years ago. The HOA has just discovered this unauthorized construction. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

A) The HOA can immediately force the owner to remove the deck, regardless of any statute of limitations.
B) The owner is not at risk of any consequences because wooden decks never require permits or licensed contractors.
C) The HOA may be limited in its ability to force removal due to a statute of limitations, but local government might still impose restrictions on future permits for the property.
D) As long as the deck is structurally sound, neither the HOA nor local government can take any action against the owner.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most accurate based on the information provided. The answer mentions that there's often a "statute of limitations that is fairly short to complain about building a structure without permission or without a proper permit." This suggests that after five years, the HOA might be limited in its ability to force removal of the deck. However, the answer also notes that local government, upon becoming aware of a structure built without a required permit (even if the statute of limitations has run), "might still deny further permits for the relevant property until the non-conforming structure is removed." This aligns with option C, which balances the potential limitations on the HOA's actions with the possible consequences from local government.

Option A is incorrect because it ignores the potential statute of limitations. Option B is wrong because it overgeneralizes about permit requirements for decks. Option D is incorrect because it assumes that structural soundness is the only factor, ignoring permit and authorization issues.

documentation.title: Hotel in Ibiza offers vouchers upon booking cancellation due to coronavirus
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I had made 2 bookings with a hotel in Ibiza with a non\-refundable rate few months ago. I used credit card to complete 2 bookings. 1 of the bookings costs less than £100, while the other costs more than £100\. I have travel insurance coverage.

Now due to Spain government legislation, all hotels are foced to close. Hence, that hotel in Ibiza had cancelled all my bookings.

Instead, that hotel offers a voucher to be spent on future booking.

Obviously, I am not satisfied with the voucher. I do not know when the Coronavirus outbreak would end. I want a full refund on my booking, not the voucher.

From legal point of view, how do I get a full refund from that hotel in Ibiza?
If that is possible, what word/quote should I use to convince/persuade that hotel in Ibiza to refund me full amount to my credit card?
What is the alternative you could suggest if the above method fails?

Thank you.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Take the voucher
----------------

**What law applies?**

Assuming you booked directly with the hotel then Spanish law applies to this contract. The hotel does not "do business" in the UK so you have no protection from UK consumer law.

If you booked through a traditional travel agent (including an online one) then your contract is with the agent and you should be sorting this out with them; not the hotel. They would be doing business in the UK and UK law would likely apply.

If you used a collation site like Expedia or Booking.com then things get complicated.

I will presume that you made the booking direct for the rest of this answer.

**What does the contract say?**

Subject to Spanish consumer protection law (which I have no knowledge of) the contract can deal with the hotel's inability to supply in whatever way it wants. I am not going to speculate about what it might say \- you have to read it.

**[Force Majeure](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/50118/what-effect-does-an-event-like-the-current-covid-19-pandemic-have-on-contractura/50119)**

Depending on when you booked, the cancellation due to government response may be a force majeure event which, under Spanish law, excuses the hotel from their contractual obligations.

It will almost certainly be such an event if, at the time you booked, the closure of the hotel by the pandemic was not reasonably foreseeable. So if you booked in 2019 or even January 2020 it probably wasn't foreseeable, if you booked last week it probably was and if you booked in between it may or may not have been.

If this is a force majeure event then the hotel owes you *nothing* \- neither refund nor voucher.

**Credit card protection**

If there was a force majeure event then the hotel is *not* in breach of their contract and [Section 75](https://www.which.co.uk/consumer-rights/regulation/section-75-of-the-consumer-credit-act) of the Consumer Credit Act will not help you. It only kicks in if the retailer made a misrepresentation or breached their contract.

**Take the voucher**

If, when all this is over, they are still in business and you are still alive, enjoy your holiday.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A traveler booked two non-refundable hotel reservations in Ibiza, Spain, a few months ago. Due to government legislation related to the Coronavirus outbreak, the hotel was forced to close and cancel all bookings. The hotel offered a voucher for future bookings instead of a refund. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the traveler's legal rights in this situation?

A) The traveler is entitled to a full refund under UK consumer protection laws.
B) The traveler can claim a refund through their credit card company using Section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act.
C) The hotel is legally obligated to provide a full refund since they cancelled the booking.
D) The traveler may not be entitled to any compensation if the cancellation is considered a force majeure event.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D because:

1. Spanish law likely applies to this contract, not UK consumer protection laws, as the hotel does not "do business" in the UK.
2. Section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act only applies if the retailer breached their contract, which may not be the case in a force majeure event.
3. If the hotel's closure due to government mandate is considered a force majeure event (which depends on when the booking was made and whether the pandemic was foreseeable at that time), the hotel may be excused from its contractual obligations.
4. In a force majeure situation, the hotel might not owe the traveler anything - neither a refund nor a voucher.

The other options are incorrect because:
A) UK consumer laws likely don't apply in this situation.
B) Credit card protection may not be applicable if there's no breach of contract due to force majeure.
C) The hotel's legal obligations depend on various factors, including the timing of the booking and the applicability of force majeure.

documentation.title: Personal Misconduct That May Result in a Lawyer's Censure or Disbarment
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is there some type of Code of (Personal) Conduct that lawyers in the United States must abide by under the penalty of either censure of disbarment? What personal kinds of personal misconduct might result in such penalties?

I am especially interested in rules of personal conduct for members of the Texas bar.

I have found lots of documentation regarding code(s) of *professional* ethics but not for *personal* ethics and behavior.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The [Texas Disciplinary Rules of Professional Conduct](https://www.texasbar.com/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&Template=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=27271) govern the issue of the grounds upon which lawyers admitted to practice in Texas may receive professional discipline such as censures, suspension from practice, or disbarment. The appropriate severity of professional discipline for particular kinds of conduct is largely a matter of case law and separate law provides for the procedural framework for administering the Rules of Professional Conduct. The Rules themselves specifically disavow the task of decided what kind if professional discipline is appropriate for any particular kind of conduct of an attorney.

Personal ethics and behavior are governed primarily by rules 8\.02 (defamatory speech about judges and other legal officials), and 8\.04 (various kinds of misconduct including personal misconduct), although there are some stray bits that can come up in connection with other rules.

Rule 1\.08 involves improper conduct in transactions with clients that do not pertain to the matter in which the client is represented (e.g. unfair business deals with clients). Texas is among a minority of states that does not automatically treat having sex with client that commences only after the attorney\-client relationship is formed as a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct.

Rule 8\.04 is sometimes called the "officer and a gentleman" clause of attorney professional ethics after an analogous provision, [Article 113](https://www.armfor.uscourts.gov/digest/IIIA59.htm), of the Uniform Code of Military Justice that applies to members of the United States armed forces. It is a residual misconduct provision that covers lots of misconduct in a lawyer's personal affairs that isn't otherwise regulated by the Rules of Professional Conduct.

Rule 8,04 and its official comments are as follows:

> Rule 8\.04\. Misconduct
> 
> 
> (a) A lawyer shall not:
> 
> 
> (1\) violate these rules, knowingly assist or induce another to do so,
> or do so through the acts of another, whether or not the violation
> occurred in the course of a client\-lawyer relationship;
> 
> 
> (2\) commit a serious crime or commit any other criminal act that
> reflects adversely on the lawyers honesty, trustworthiness or fitness
> as a lawyer in other respects;
> 
> 
> (3\) engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or
> misrepresentation;
> 
> 
> (4\) engage in conduct constituting obstruction of justice;
> 
> 
> (5\) state or imply an ability to influence improperly a government
> agency or official;
> 
> 
> (6\) knowingly assist a judge or judicial officer in conduct that is a
> violation of applicable rules of judicial conduct or other law;
> 
> 
> (7\) violate any disciplinary or disability order or judgment;
> 
> 
> (8\) fail to timely furnish to the Chief Disciplinary Counsels office
> or a district grievance committee a response or other information as
> required by the Texas Rules of Disciplinary Procedure, unless he or
> she in good faith timely asserts a privilege or other legal ground for
> failure to do so;
> 
> 
> (9\) engage in conduct that constitutes barratry as defined by the law
> of this state;
> 
> 
> (10\) fail to comply with section 13\.01 of the Texas Rules of
> Disciplinary Procedure relating to notification of an attorneys
> cessation of practice;
> 
> 
> (11\) engage in the practice of law when the lawyer is on inactive
> status, except as permitted by section 81\.053 of the Government Code
> and Article XIII of the State Bar Rules, or when the lawyers right to
> practice has been suspended or terminated, including, but not limited
> to, situations where a lawyer’s right to practice has been
> administratively suspended for failure to timely pay required fees or
> assessments or for failure to comply with Article XII of the State Bar
> Rules relating to Mandatory Continuing Legal Education; or
> 
> 
> (12\) violate any other laws of this state relating to the professional
> conduct of lawyers and to the practice of law.
> 
> 
> (b) As used in subsection (a)(2\) of this Rule, “serious crime” means
> barratry; any felony involving moral turpitude; any misdemeanor
> involving theft, embezzlement, or fraudulent or reckless
> misappropriation of money or other property; or any attempt,
> conspiracy, or solicitation of another to commit any of the foregoing
> crimes.
> 
> 
> Comment:
> 
> 
> 1. There are four principal sources of professional obligations for lawyers in Texas: these rules, the State Bar Act, the State Bar Rules,
> and the Texas Rules of Disciplinary Procedure (TRDP). All lawyers are
> presumed to know the requirements of these sources. Rule 8\.04(a)(1\)
> provides a partial list of conduct that will subject a lawyer to
> discipline.
> 2. Many kinds of illegal conduct reflect adversely on fitness to practice law. However, some kinds of offenses carry no such
> implication. Traditionally in this state, the distinction has been
> drawn in terms of those crimes subjecting a lawyer to compulsory
> discipline, criminal acts relevant to a lawyer’s fitness for the
> practice of law, and other offenses. Crimes subject to compulsory
> discipline are governed by TRDP, Part VIII. In addition, although a
> lawyer is personally answerable to the entire criminal law, a lawyer
> should be professionally answerable only for criminal acts that
> indicate a lack of those characteristics relevant to the lawyer’s
> fitness for the practice of law. A pattern of repeated criminal acts,
> even ones of minor significance when considered separately, can
> indicate indifference to legal obligations that legitimately could
> call a lawyer’s overall fitness to practice into question. See TRDP,
> Part VIII; Rule 8\.04(a)(2\).
> 3. A lawyer may refuse to comply with an obligation imposed by law upon a good faith belief, openly asserted, that no valid obligation
> exists. The provisions of Rule 1\.02(c) concerning a good faith
> challenge to the validity, scope, meaning or application of the law
> apply to challenges to legal regulation of the practice of law.
> 4. Lawyers holding public office assume legal responsibilities going beyond those of other citizens. A lawyer’s abuse of public office can
> suggest an inability to fulfill the professional role of attorney. The
> same is true of abuse of positions of private trust.

With respect to the portion of the question asking:

> What personal kinds of personal misconduct might result in such
> penalties?

Some of the most serious violations of the rules that are likely to lead to disbarment include misappropriation of client property, abandonment of a legal practice with active clients, revealing highly prejudicial client confidences with no color of justification for doing so, committing a crime involving fraud or a felony, or failure to cooperate with a disciplinary investigation.

Of those, committing of a crime involving fraud or a felony would be the one most likely to result in disbarment that involves *personal conduct*, as opposed to professional conduct. Other kinds of personal conduct might result in a lesser sanction, however, as noted in Rule 8\.4\. Of course, it isn't all that hard to imagine some circumstance "involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation" (think "[George Santos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Santos)" absent any criminal conduct) that isn't strictly speaking a crime, or "conduct constituting obstruction of justice" in a matter unrelated to client matters (e.g. obstructing an investigation of a family member of the lawyer in connection with an academic institution's investigation) that could rise to this level as well.

But, again, the matching of punishment to particular conduct is rooted in case law. Also, a pattern of various kinds of misconduct or repeat offenses are often treatment more seriously than a single instance of misconduct by a first offender would be in isolation.

Incidentally, every U.S. jurisdiction has a set of Rules of Professional Conduct with the same numbering system, although the substantive content of different states' rules with the same number is not always the same.

So, for example, Rule 8\.4 covers the same subject\-matter in every U.S. state, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and every other U.S. territory, even though there may be important substantive differences between the versions of Rule 8\.4 adopted in different states.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A Texas lawyer engages in personal conduct outside of their professional duties that involves:

1. Committing a misdemeanor for reckless driving
2. Making a false statement on a mortgage application
3. Having a consensual sexual relationship with a current client
4. Failing to file personal income taxes for two years

Which of these actions is MOST likely to result in disbarment according to the Texas Disciplinary Rules of Professional Conduct?

A) The reckless driving misdemeanor
B) The false statement on a mortgage application
C) The sexual relationship with a current client
D) The failure to file personal income taxes

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the Texas Disciplinary Rules of Professional Conduct, particularly Rule 8.04, the action most likely to result in disbarment is B) The false statement on a mortgage application. This falls under conduct "involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation" which is explicitly prohibited by Rule 8.04(a)(3). It also potentially constitutes a crime involving fraud, which is considered a "serious crime" under Rule 8.04(b) and can lead to severe disciplinary action.

Option A, while a criminal act, is less likely to be considered as severely unless it's part of a pattern of repeated offenses.

Option C, while potentially unethical, is not automatically treated as a violation in Texas, unlike in some other states.

Option D, while serious, might not necessarily lead to disbarment on its own, especially if rectified, though it could lead to disciplinary action.

The false statement on a mortgage application most directly challenges a lawyer's honesty and trustworthiness, which are fundamental to the profession, making it the most likely to result in disbarment among these options.

documentation.title: Is the Benchmarking clause in VMware's EULA actually valid?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The [VMware End User License Agreement](https://www.vmware.com/download/eula/universal_eula.html) reads as follows: 

> **2\.4 Benchmarking.** You may use the Software to conduct internal performance testing and benchmarking studies. You may only publish or otherwise distribute the results of such studies to third parties as follows: (a) if with respect to VMware’s Workstation or Fusion products, only if You provide a copy of Your study to benchmark@vmware.com prior to distribution; (b) if with respect to any other Software, only if VMware has reviewed and approved of the methodology, assumptions and other parameters of the study (please contact VMware at benchmark@vmware.com to request such review and approval) prior to such publication and distribution.

My questions are:

* What happens, if you refuse to take your unapproved benchmark down? Can they sue you?
* How much leg does a clause like this stand on the courts? In the United States? In the rest of the world?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: IANAL, but a EULA is a Contract of Adhesion <https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/adhesion_contract_contract_of_adhesion> and restrictions against publishing benchmarking data about products is fairly common [https://www.eff.org/wp/dangerous\-terms\-users\-guide\-eulas](https://www.eff.org/wp/dangerous-terms-users-guide-eulas)

A contract is a contract, even a click\-through, and is legally binding; there is plenty supporting case law. You sign when you click: [http://smallbusiness.findlaw.com/business\-operations/contracts\-and\-electronic\-signatures.html](http://smallbusiness.findlaw.com/business-operations/contracts-and-electronic-signatures.html)

Basically, VMware has lots more money than you do. If they are annoyed at your posting of benchmarks that don't make their products look as good as they feel they should, they can at very least send a DMCA to the site that posts the benchmarks. Whether that works could depend on where the website is hosted. At most, they could take you to civil court, if you are in their jurisdiction.

> What happens, if you refuse to take your unapproved benchmark down?
>  Can they sue you?

Yes. (In civil, not criminal court).

> How much leg does a clause like this stand on the courts? In the
>  United States?

A contract is a contract. And VMware and you (I assume) are in the US, so the contract is enforceable.

> In the rest of the world?

Outside of the US, enforceability is variable; that is searchable in law databases for each country and agreements between countries.

Consider your motives for posting benchmarks against VMware's EULA. Do you have good points to make? Or are you simply complaining about the product? Who has more money to spend defending or fighting the EULA? You or them?

*If you're seriously concerned about this, talk to a lawyer and don't take legal advice from the general public.*

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to the VMware End User License Agreement (EULA) and the legal analysis provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the publication of benchmarking results for VMware products?

A) The EULA's restrictions on publishing benchmarks are not legally enforceable because they limit free speech.

B) Users can freely publish benchmarks for any VMware product as long as they provide a copy to VMware after distribution.

C) The EULA's restrictions on benchmarking are legally binding in the US, and VMware can potentially sue users who violate these terms.

D) Users can publish benchmarks without VMware's approval if the study is conducted outside the United States.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The information provided indicates that the EULA is a legally binding contract in the United States, even as a click-through agreement. The EULA specifically restricts the publication of benchmarking results without VMware's approval for most of their products. The analysis states that VMware can potentially sue users who violate these terms in civil court. 

Option A is incorrect because the EULA is described as enforceable, despite potential free speech concerns. 

Option B is incorrect as it misrepresents the EULA's requirements; for most products, VMware must review and approve the methodology before publication, not just receive a copy after distribution. 

Option D is incorrect because while enforceability may vary outside the US, the question doesn't provide enough information to conclude that benchmarks can be freely published internationally, and the EULA itself doesn't make this distinction.

documentation.title: Does creating an unpaid event poster for a commercial event constitute commercial use?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Licenses of artworks or stock photos often state that they are free for non\-commercial use.

Assume I create a poster for an event. I do not sell the poster, but the event is commercial (has an entry fee. or sells drinks. or something like that). Am I then allowed to use that stock photo?

For example, [pexels](https://www.pexels.com/photo-license/) states

> All photos on Pexels can be used for free for commercial and
>  noncommercial use.  
> 
>  Attribution is not required.  
> 
>  Giving credit to the
>  photographer or Pexels is not necessary but always appreciated.  
> 
>  You
>  can modify the photos. Be creative and edit the photos as you like.

I am interested in an internationally accepted answer, if there is one. Otherwise, I am interested in US, European Union, and Swiss law.

Related questions, but without any sources (and so seem like the answers could just as well be somebody's opinion): 

* [Do Portfolio Projects Count As Commercial Use](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/21550/do-portfolio-projects-count-as-commercial-use)
* [The Scope Of Free\-For\-Personal\-Use Fonts](https://graphicdesign.stackexchange.com/questions/82544/the-scope-of-free-for-personal-use-in-fonts)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: *Commercial* means related to commerce and *commerce* means the activity of buying and selling. Advertising material for a commercial event is itself commercial. If the licence restriction is for non\-commercial use only then you are outside the licence. However, the licence you quote allows both.

12.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A local charity is organizing a fundraising event where attendees pay an entry fee. The organizers want to create promotional posters using stock photos. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the use of stock photos for this event?

A) Stock photos marked as "free for non-commercial use" can be used without restriction since it's a charity event.
B) Any stock photo can be used as long as credit is given to the photographer, regardless of the license terms.
C) Stock photos from Pexels can be used for the event posters without attribution, even though the event charges an entry fee.
D) Only stock photos specifically labeled for commercial use should be considered, as promotional materials for events with entry fees are considered commercial use.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The question tests understanding of commercial use in the context of stock photo licensing. Option A is incorrect because even charity events with entry fees are considered commercial use. Option B is wrong as credit requirements vary by license and don't override usage restrictions. Option D is overly restrictive.

Option C is correct because Pexels explicitly allows both commercial and non-commercial use without requiring attribution, making their photos suitable for this scenario. The fundraising event, despite its charitable nature, is considered commercial use due to the entry fee, but Pexels photos can still be used freely in this context according to their license terms.

documentation.title: Can charities be granted patents on medicine?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Can a charity patent a medicine that it invents?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If they meet the requirements for a patent including being a legal person, yes.

13.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A non-profit medical research foundation, dedicated to finding cures for rare diseases, has developed a breakthrough medication. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the foundation's ability to patent this medication?

A) The foundation cannot patent the medication because it is a non-profit organization.
B) The foundation can patent the medication only if it establishes a for-profit subsidiary.
C) The foundation can patent the medication if it meets all standard patent requirements and is recognized as a legal person.
D) The foundation must transfer the patent rights to a pharmaceutical company to secure the patent.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, a charity (which would include a non-profit foundation) can patent a medicine it invents if it meets the requirements for a patent and is recognized as a legal person. Being a non-profit organization does not disqualify an entity from obtaining a patent. The foundation does not need to establish a for-profit subsidiary or transfer rights to a pharmaceutical company to secure the patent. The key factors are meeting standard patent requirements (such as novelty, non-obviousness, and usefulness) and having legal personhood, which most established non-profit organizations possess.

documentation.title: What is the color of caution or warning of hazard sign?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is the following caution or warning of hazard sign orange or yellow? My impression is that it's color yellow, but the [link](https://www.alberta.ca/sign-shapes-and-colours.aspx) says it's color orange. And even though the aforementioned link says caution or warning of hazard sign only has one color, in this other [link](https://www.alberta.ca/warning-signs.aspx) there is more than one color (yellow, green). In addition, there is more than just one shape (diamond shape, rectangular). Thank you!

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/tqFmF.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/tqFmF.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **The picture you posted is of a yellow sign mislabeled as orange.**

While some tints can be distorted depending on computer screens and color settings and individual perceptions may vary, verification of this specific example can be made by the context provided in your link.

Below you can see the published example of a construction area sign:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/D6LjO.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/D6LjO.png)

Several places below that is the one you posted in your question:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/PxbIO.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/PxbIO.png)

As you can clearly see the colors are distinctly different, yet the color description is the same. It's apparent that the graphic artist who created this copied their work and changed the color, but forgot to change the text. *Trust your eyes!*

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding warning signs in Alberta, Canada?

A) All warning signs are yellow diamond-shaped signs with black symbols or text.

B) Warning signs can only be orange or yellow in color, always in a diamond shape.

C) Warning signs are consistently labeled as orange in official documentation, even when they appear yellow.

D) Warning signs can vary in color (including yellow and green) and shape (including diamond and rectangular), despite some inconsistencies in official labeling.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because the information provided shows that warning signs can come in colors other than yellow and shapes other than diamond.

Option B is incorrect as the second link demonstrates that warning signs can be green as well, and can have rectangular shapes.

Option C is incorrect. While there is an instance of mislabeling a yellow sign as orange in the official documentation, this is clearly an error and not a consistent practice.

Option D is correct. The information provided shows that warning signs in Alberta can indeed vary in color (including yellow and green) and shape (including diamond and rectangular). The inconsistency in labeling (where a yellow sign is mislabeled as orange) actually supports the idea that there's some variation and potential for confusion in the official categorization of these signs.

documentation.title: Can sole member LLC add 1% partnership to deduct large business expenses?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A sole member LLC has business expenses that can only be partially deducted from the individual's taxes because they far exceed the company's income.

The company changes to a partnership adding an individual but with only 1% interest.

The new partner contributes cash to the company to cover the business expense deficit and then deducts that same amount as a business expense from their new company from the taxes on their own existing income.

By diverting an amount that would have been paid to the IRS to their new company and then deducting that same amount, the overall transaction nets to zero but the company covers it's business expenses.

Can partners only deduct business expenses proportional to their interest in the company?

Even if they made an equivalent cash contribution to the company?

Can someone only deduct business expenses from taxes on income from that business only or all of their income regardless of the source?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Contributing cash to a company is not tax deductible
----------------------------------------------------

It’s either a capital contribution or a loan; either way it’s not an expense deductible to the individual (nor income to the company).

15.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A sole proprietor LLC with significant business expenses exceeding its income decides to convert to a partnership by adding a new partner with a 1% interest. The new partner contributes cash to cover the business expense deficit. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tax implications of this arrangement?

A) The new partner can deduct the entire cash contribution as a business expense on their personal tax return, regardless of their ownership percentage.

B) The new partner can only deduct business expenses proportional to their 1% interest in the company.

C) The cash contribution by the new partner is considered a tax-deductible business expense for the company.

D) The cash contribution is either a capital contribution or a loan, and is not tax-deductible for the new partner nor taxable income for the company.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. Contributing cash to a company, whether as a new partner or an existing one, is not considered a tax-deductible business expense. It is either treated as a capital contribution, which increases the partner's basis in the company, or as a loan to the company. Neither of these scenarios results in a tax deduction for the contributing partner or taxable income for the receiving company. The other options are incorrect because they mischaracterize the nature of the cash contribution and its tax implications. Business expenses can generally be deducted against all income sources, not just income from the specific business, but a cash contribution itself is not a business expense.

documentation.title: Contact Microsoft legal department, or other ways to facilitate reinstatement of a Google Play app
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I used an icon of Microsoft Notepad (taken from Wikipedia) as the icon for a free [Notepad application Fast Notepad](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.notes.notepad) in Google Play. It probably was beneficial for the community, as it had no ads, and many users could use it for education, and they accepted it with a high rating of 4\.7\. But currently it is **suspended** by Google Play, presumably because of the icon. So legal permissions for the image need to be discussed to handle copyright issues. 

If the app is reinstated for a short time, so I can change the icon to another, this will be the desired result. I have not yet filed an appeal (the owner of a suspended app can send a proof of their rights, but only once).

**Is there a means to contact Microsoft legal department or similar on this issue or another way** of solving the problem? Any information would help.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **Yes**

Best is to call them and let them guide you to the right department.

[https://www.microsoft.com/en\-gb/contact.aspx](https://www.microsoft.com/en-gb/contact.aspx)

In reality you can give up. They will never ever give you the permission to use the icon, even if you'd pay for it.

Why? Because as soon they give the permission to someone others will try to use it too and their legal stand would be more difficult since they softenend the use rights of that icon/intellectual property, opening doors for people who copy without thinking of the legal implications and scammers.

EDIT: To add; As far I know you're not allowed to take stuff from wikipedia without noticing them/linking to them. That your app is free also doesn't matters. Maybe you're even showing ads in your app giving it a commercial goal.

16.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An app developer used a Microsoft Notepad icon from Wikipedia for their free Android app, which was subsequently suspended by Google Play. What is the most appropriate course of action for the developer to resolve this copyright issue?

A) File an immediate appeal with Google Play, claiming fair use of the icon for educational purposes
B) Contact Microsoft's legal department to request permission to use the icon
C) Change the app icon to an original design and request temporary reinstatement from Google Play
D) Argue that using the icon was beneficial for the community due to the app's high rating and lack of ads

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the most appropriate course of action for several reasons:

1. Changing the icon to an original design addresses the root cause of the suspension without relying on uncertain legal permissions.
2. Requesting temporary reinstatement to update the icon is a practical approach that demonstrates willingness to comply with copyright laws.
3. This option avoids potential legal conflicts with Microsoft and aligns with Google Play's policies.

Option A is incorrect because fair use claims are complex and often unsuccessful in commercial contexts, even for free apps. 

Option B is unlikely to succeed, as the documentation suggests Microsoft would be reluctant to grant permission for icon use to avoid setting a precedent.

Option D is not a valid legal argument, as community benefit and app ratings do not override copyright protections.

documentation.title: Is it legal to paraphrase a paid Wall Street Journal article in its entirety and publish the paraphrased article for free?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I know that in many countries republishing any web article from another website without consent is considered a form of plagery and copyright enfringement and is therefore illegal.

But I *am* looking to republish a couple of paid articles from wsj.com on my own website. According to [the Wall Street Journal's terms of use](http://www.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/reprints-wsj-terms.html) i may be required to pay them a licensing fee first in order to get permission to reproduce the articles.

However I don't have a lot of money and therefore don't want to pay any licensing fee. So my idea was to just read every article i want to republish and then write a paraphrased version of the article to put on my website. This paraphrased article would have completely different sentences compared to the original article but would describe the same information nonetheless. Would it be legal for me to publish such an article on my website without having to pay a licensing fee to The Wall Street Journal?

I am mentioning the Wall Street Journal in this thread, but my question applies to the paid articles of other online news websites as well. So to put the question more broadly: **what does US law say about reproducing a copyrighted article in a paraphrased or summarized form?** Is it legal or illegal to do so without prior consent?

**EDIT:** Jen posted two useful links in the comments of two other law stackexchange threads that are about the same subject as this thread. However none of the answers in those threads quote the relevant part(s) from US law. I would like to know what US law says about paraphrasing an article and i would like the answer to **include quotations from US law**.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: U.S. law says in [17 U.S.C. 102(b)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/102)

> In no case does copyright protection for an original work of
> authorship extend to any idea, procedure, process, system, method of
> operation, concept, principle, or discovery, regardless of the form in
> which it is described, explained, illustrated, or embodied in such
> work.

So, if you do not copy wording, just information and ideas, there should not be copyright violations. I do not see the WSJ TOS mentioning a license required to summarize or rewrite their material.

It is fundamental that copyright protects the expression of ideas (among other things) but *not* ideas or information. The subtlety with "information" is that, in some places like most of Europe a collection of organized information of non\-copyrightable material can be copyrighted as a whole.

That is not the case in the U.S. although there was an unsuccessful attempt in the Database and Collections of Information Misappropriation Act of 2003/4\.

Also, plagiarism, appropriation of ideas without attribution, is an academic integrity issue, not a legal issue.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to U.S. copyright law, which of the following actions would most likely be considered legal without obtaining permission or paying a licensing fee?

A) Copying and republishing entire articles from the Wall Street Journal website on your own website
B) Paraphrasing articles from the Wall Street Journal, using different wording but conveying the same information and ideas
C) Reproducing select sentences and paragraphs from Wall Street Journal articles, with attribution
D) Creating a database of Wall Street Journal article headlines and publication dates

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option B is correct according to U.S. copyright law. The law, specifically 17 U.S.C. 102(b), states that copyright protection does not extend to ideas, concepts, or information, regardless of the form in which they are described. Paraphrasing articles using different wording but conveying the same information and ideas would likely be legal, as long as the specific expression (wording) is not copied.

Option A is illegal as it involves directly copying copyrighted material without permission. 
Option C would likely infringe on copyright as it involves reproducing portions of the original text. 
Option D, while not directly infringing copyright, could potentially be problematic in the U.S. if it's considered a substantial collection of factual information, though this is less clear-cut than the other options.

It's important to note that while paraphrasing may avoid copyright issues, it could still be considered plagiarism in academic or professional contexts if proper attribution is not given.

documentation.title: I'm owed compensation for assault. It's been almost 8 years and I haven't seen a penny
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: \[Oxfordshire, England] When I was 15 \[I am 22 now], I was mugged and beaten up by a group of three young men, the youngest of this group being 18\. I called the Police, and the guys were caught. As it turned out, only 1 of these guys got any sort of punishment, was sentenced to a number of hours public service and a £200 fine for assault on a minor.

I haven't seen a penny and it's almost been a decade. I was never advised by the police as to how to follow up this inquiry and I feel so betrayed by the British justice system.

The last I heard of this was that the guy who owes me was on benefits so he wasn't able to pay me a lump sum but surely the State should've stopped paying this guy benefits since he goes around lamping kids?

Is there anyone who knows how I can follow this up?

I understand that the money I'm owed isn't a whole lot, but it's the principle that this guy as an adult attacked a kid for no reason and isn't even paying the full price for it even though it left me with huge anxiety issues later on in my life.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The important question is: was the £200 a fine (which is paid to the state) or compensation (which is paid to you)?

Assuming it was a fine
----------------------

He doesn't (at the moment) owe you anything. However you can sue him for damages. Usually a claim for damages is time\-barred after six years (and it is now seven years). However you weren't able to sue him yourself until you were 18, so you may have a couple of years left. However the clock may have started ticking immediately after the attack, on the grounds your parents or guardians could have sued. Talk to a solictor about this possibility; they should give you a free 30 minute consultation, and would probably take a case on a contigency fee (no\-win no\-fee) basis if it has any chance.

In principle, you could have applied to the [Criminal Injuries Compensation Board](https://www.gov.uk/claim-compensation-criminal-injury/eligibility) for compensation \- but you are too late for that; you have to apply within two years (there are some exceptions, but none seem to apply to you).

Assuming it was compensation
----------------------------

He owes you £200\. Now you need to enforce that payment \- and again, the problem may be the six year clock. You will definitely need to talk to a lawyer about that.

My gut feeling is that the £200 was probably a fine rather than compensation.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the case of a victim of assault seeking compensation years after the incident, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal options available?

A) The victim can always claim compensation from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board, regardless of how much time has passed since the incident.

B) If the £200 was a fine rather than compensation, the victim has no further legal recourse to seek damages from the attacker.

C) The victim may still have a chance to sue for damages, even after 7 years, due to the fact that they were a minor at the time of the incident.

D) The state is obligated to pay the victim the £200 if the attacker was on benefits and unable to pay.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most accurate statement based on the information provided. While there is typically a six-year limitation period for civil claims, the clock may not have started ticking until the victim turned 18, potentially giving them a couple more years to pursue legal action. This is because minors are generally not able to sue on their own behalf. However, the victim would need to consult with a solicitor to determine if this exception applies in their specific case.

Option A is incorrect because claims to the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board must typically be made within two years of the incident, with some exceptions that don't seem to apply here.

Option B is incorrect because even if the £200 was a fine, the victim may still have the option to sue for damages separately, subject to time limitations.

Option D is incorrect because the state is not obligated to pay the victim on behalf of the attacker, even if the attacker is on benefits.

documentation.title: does a purposive approach of statuary construction neccesarily always favour a state in a trial?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: the purposive approach choses the interpretation that furthers the purpose of a legislature. but does it take into account things like if a broadly worded law was intended to he applicable to particular cases or not (example if such a case was taken into account, would the drafters want the case to fall within th scope of the law or not)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It does not, as prosecutors often use statutes for purposes other than the purposes for which they were intended. *See*, *e.g.*, [*Yates v. United States*, 135 S. Ct. 1074 (2014\)](https://casetext.com/case/yates-v-united-states-26).

For a very straightforward example, take the classic law school hypothetical: A law that says "No cars in the park."

If you drive your truck into the park, a purposivist approach would permit your conviction for violating the statute. In that case, purposivism favors the state.

But if you bring a Matchbox car into the park, a purposivist approach would not permit your conviction for violating the staute. In that case, purposivism favors the defendant.

And of course, prosecutors are a creative bunch, so they're forever coming up with new ways to existing statutes to prosecute people using statutes that aren't a natural fit for their misconduct.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A city passes an ordinance stating "No vehicles in the park." The city council's primary intention was to reduce noise pollution and ensure pedestrian safety. Which of the following scenarios would most likely be interpreted as violating this ordinance under the purposive approach to legal interpretation?

A) A child brings a toy remote-controlled car to play with in the park
B) A group of teenagers ride their bicycles through the park
C) A disabled person uses an electric wheelchair to navigate the park paths
D) A maintenance worker drives a lawn mower to cut the grass in the park

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
The purposive approach to legal interpretation aims to further the legislature's intent when applying a law. In this case, the city council's primary goals were reducing noise pollution and ensuring pedestrian safety.

Option A (toy car) would likely not violate the ordinance as it doesn't significantly contribute to noise pollution or endanger pedestrians.

Option B (bicycles) is the most likely to be considered a violation under the purposive approach. While bicycles are not motor vehicles, they can pose a safety risk to pedestrians and potentially cause noise, aligning with the council's intentions.

Option C (electric wheelchair) would likely be exempt due to accessibility considerations, even under a purposive approach.

Option D (lawn mower) might technically fit the definition of a "vehicle," but its use is essential for park maintenance and would likely be considered an exception.

The question highlights how the purposive approach can lead to interpretations that may not strictly adhere to the literal wording of a law, but instead focus on achieving the law's intended purpose.

documentation.title: In Florida, can a home defense weapon and use of "Castle Doctrine" (deadly force) transfer to a house of a friend that I visit?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose I am entitled to use a weapon for home defense in the state of Florida. If I visit a friend for say 1 week, would the Castle Doctrine apply if an uninvited intruder entered the house of my friend and threatened my life (or the life of my friend), even though it is not my normal place of dwelling? Specifically, I am asking if the Castle Doctrine applies ONLY to your main places of dwelling such as the persons car and house, or if it can extended to a friends house you are visiting (and sleeping at). The friends house is also in Florida.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Generally, yes. Castle doctrine generally applies to anyone who is not trespassing on the property, not just the property owner. So long as you have permission from the property owner to be there, you can invoke Castle Doctrine.

It should be noted that Castle Doctrine is not a law, but rather a legal theory of a narrow self\-defense claim. In general, Self\-Defense in the United States breaks down to "Duty to Flee" vs. "Stand Your Ground" with the latter being much more common in the U.S. while all 50 states have Castle Doctrine in a private space (three do not have it codified but rely on state laws). Castle Doctrine simply means you have a legal right to "stand your ground" on your own private property regardless of the state's "Duty to Flee" stance in public spaces.

Florida is a "Stand Your Ground" state for purposes of self\-defense, which means that, so long as you have a legal right to be in a space, you have the right to use deadly force in self\-defense even if you can retreat from the situation. And it's not something Floridians are shy about either. The concept of the "Stand your Ground" vs. "Duty to Retreat" entered into public debate a few years back during the Zimmerman case, where it was used successfully for Zimmerman to be found not guilty of murder of a teenage African American boy.

As a personal annecdote I like to tell, when I live in Florida, my boss walked into work the other day and was discussing his recent purchase of a gun and how, when asked by the police what the purpose of his gun purchase was, he answered to defend his home. The cop took him aside and said, "Just so you know, if you ever have to use that gun to defend your home, you need to know how to do it properly... Shoot to kill. It's less paperwork for us."

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In Florida, under what circumstances can the Castle Doctrine be invoked by a visitor staying at a friend's house?

A) Only if the visitor is a permanent resident of the house
B) Only if the visitor has been staying at the house for more than 30 days
C) If the visitor has the property owner's permission to be there and is facing an imminent threat
D) Only if the visitor is a family member of the property owner

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Castle Doctrine in Florida applies to anyone who is legally present on a property, not just the property owner. As long as a visitor has permission from the property owner to be there, they can invoke the Castle Doctrine if faced with an imminent threat from an intruder. Florida is also a "Stand Your Ground" state, which means that individuals have the right to use deadly force in self-defense if they have a legal right to be in a space, even if retreat is possible. This applies not only to one's own home but also to places where one is staying as a guest, such as a friend's house. The other options are incorrect because the Castle Doctrine does not require permanent residency, a specific duration of stay, or family relation to the property owner.

documentation.title: Is scraping real estate data illegal in anyway?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So a relative of mine works in the real estate business and she wants me to write a Python script that scrapes property prices and lot size from a website, calculate price per sqft, and email her the address and property price if the ppsqft is less than 200 dollars..
